1.0    Executive Summary



1.1    Introduction



The Harrodsburg Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is required to prepare this Risk Management Plan under EPA regulation 40 CFR Part 68 due to the storage of chlorine in quantities greater than the threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds.  The facility poses a certain risk to the community since chlorine is a flammable/explosive material.  This plan outlines the facilities plans to minimize that risk and displays the efforts and resources put into the accident prevention program. 



1.2    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



1.2.1    Process Safety Information



Process Safety Information (PSI) pertains to any process which is covered under the RMP regulations and shall be used to enable the employer and employees to understand and identify hazards involved with chlorine while operating.  For the purpose of identifying the hazards of chlorine, a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) is provided in Appendix B.  



The maximum intended inventory is three 2,000 lb cylinders of compressed chlorine located inside the facility.  The chlorine is then fed from the cylinders to different areas of the treatment system via underground piping.  



If the air within the chlorine room becomes unsafe due to a chlorine leak, there are detection sensors that trigger alarms and lights which notify the employees and the local fire department.  



Information pertaining to the equipment in the process can be found in the office of the plant superintendent and may be viewed by employees upon request.  These specifications include materials of construction, piping and instrument diagrams, ventilation system design, design codes and standards employed, and safety systems.  The equipment used at the plant complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.



1.2.2    Operating Procedures



To change a chlorine cylinder the WWTP has developed the following standard operating procedure (SOP) to provide empl

oyees with clear written procedures to follow.  

1.    Make sure no alarms are going off prior to entering the chlorine room

2.    Turn exhaust fan and light on upon entering chlorine room

3.    At least two people must be present (one of which could be the driver delivering the chlorine) and one should be outside the room

4.    Employees must wear a full face shield and neoprene or pvc gloves prior to handling chlorine

5.    Turn the chlorine at both cylinders off using the main valves

6.    Use the hoist according to the annual safety training received from the city to remove the two empty cylinders and replace with two new ones

7.    Turn the main valves back on 

8.    Check for leaks

9.    Turn the exhaust fan and light back off upon leaving the chlorine room



***If chlorine vapor is detected, immediately evacuate the area and call 911 when at a safe distance from the area.



The following procedure must be observed at all times when connecting a cylinder to a supply line/manifold.



1. Secure the cylinders on the scale with a safety chain before removing the protective

cylinder hoods.

2. Remove the brass outlet cap found on a ton container outlet valve.

3. Remove any foreign material that may be in the outlet valve recess. Place a new lead washer on the inlet adapter portion of the cylinder or container yoke. Never reuse an old lead washer.

4. Place the yoke over the outlet valve and insert the inlet adapter into the valve. Make sure that the inlet adapter and lead washer seat firmly against the outlet valve. Then tighten the yoke screw until the yoke is snug on the outlet valve.

5. Only use the cylinder or container valve wrench provided by the chemical supplier to tighten the yoke or operate the outlet valve. Never, under any circumstance, use a pipe wrench or any ill fitting wrench on the yoke/outlet valve since this will "round off" the soft metal of the square valve stem. Do not use any wrench that is over ten inches in length to open a stubborn valve because of th

e danger of bending or breaking the valve stem. To open a stubborn valve, use a small block of wood in the palm of the hand and strike the appropriate valve wrench. If the valve still will not open, call the chemical supplier immediately. Do not make any extraordinary attempts to open a stubborn valve. There is a risk to your life and/or the public may be endangered if any further means to open the valve are taken.



For procedures that will be used in dealing with a leak or spill of chlorine see the section titled Emergency Response Program.



SOP's shall be reviewed by operators of the process to verify all necessary procedures are included with easy-to-understand instructions.



1.3    Description of the Facility and Regulated Substances



The plant is located in Harrodsburg (Mercer County), Kentucky at coordinates 37A?46'35"N and 84A?52'03" W.  The property is located along Cornishville Road in a rural area and is bordered primarily by residential farmland.  The facility treats a mixture of domestic, commercial, and industrial wastewater from the City of Harrodsburg.  With a design capacity of 2.68 MGD, the facility uses screening, settling, rotating biological contactors as well as a settling lagoon system to achieve treatment.  Chlorination and sulfur dioxide are used for disinfection and de-chlorination.





Facility Owner and Operator:

City of Harrodsburg

965 Cornishville Road

Harrodsburg, KY 

Telephone 859-734-2113



Chlorine is stored inside the facility in two 2,000 lb cylinders (see Figure  for chlorine storage and handling areas).  The chlorine is converted at this location from a liquid phase to a gas phase to be used within the treatment process. The gas is then transported via an underground pipeline to the different areas of the plant including the chlorine contact basin, lagoons 1, 2, 3, and 4, the plant influent, and the sludge mixing box.



1.4    Process Hazard Assessment Results



It is the responsibility of the Harrodsburg WWTP to perfor

m Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) on all processes held at the facility which are covered under the RMP.  The PHA shall identify, evaluate, and control the hazards of chlorine processes by utilizing a what-if checklist.  The checklist is found below:



What if?



The following items discuss some of the hazards scenarios which might be associated with the chlorination process.  While not all items are posed with the words "what if", readers should consider these items with "what if this happened ?" or "what if I didn't do it this way ?"



Special care should be taken to inspect all lines on at least an annual basis.  Even Schedule 80 PVC becomes brittle over time when exposed to chlorinated water.



A check of the chlorine alarm system should be performed on at least a annual basis.  The chemical supplier, Living Waters of Cincinnati, should be contacted for assistance if needed (502)-863-2874).  If the alarm system fails in the event of a chlorine leak, an employee could easily be overcome upon entering the building.



Also, on a annual basis, the blowoff lines should be checked to see that they are clear.  Insects have rarely been known to plug these lines with nest material.



If a chlorine cylinder is not seated properly in the floor boots they may move once on the manifold and break the transfer lines and release chlorine.  This supposes that the vacuum cutoff fails.  Valves on the cylinders should always be closed tightly before and during cylinder changes



If any of the ejectors, flow tubes or controllers become damaged chlorine may escape in large quantities.  This supposes that the vacuum lock devices on one of the cylinders fails simultaneously.  As with all system components, these devices should be inspected at least quarterly for corrosion, damage or hairline fractures.



Water supply valves should always be open before operating the system with positive chlorine pressure.  Without water flow in the system, gaseous chlorine may be discharged to th

e flash mix or clearwell resulting in high concentrations in the atmosphere around the plant.



No emergency operation of the system will be attempted.  Unless the system can be operated in a normal fashion it will not be operated at all.  Emergency shutdown can be accomplished properly only by shutoff of the main cylinder valve.



A copy of the PHA shall be retained for the life of the process and shall be updated and re-evaluated at a minimum of every five years to assure it is consistent with the current process.



1.5    General Accidental Release Prevention Program/ Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



1.5.1    Training



In order to become proficient in responding to emergencies at the plant, a regular schedule of training must be maintained. It shall include the following components



Chemical Training



At least once a year, all operators must undergo training on the various hazardous materials located around the plant. This training may include handouts, audio/visual tapes and lectures.  Training provided at KWWOA, KRWA, or Central Kentucky Technical Center (Lawrenceburg) may be substituted for on-site training.  A written examination based on the information presented at the training session will be given at the discretion of the plant supervisor.



Inspection of Equipment



At least once a year a careful examination of all gas lines, valves, injectors and water feed lines will be made.  PVC lines in particular tend to become brittle after long term contact with chlorine.  Replacement of faulty, damaged or suspect parts should be made immediately.



Safety Inspections



The Harrodsburg Fire Department will conduct a fire safety inspection on an annual basis.  The inspection report will be kept at the wastewater plant main office.



1.5.2    Contractors



In the event a contractor is to be hired to perform maintenance, repair, major renovation, or specialty work on or near a process covered by the RMP, it is the responsibility of the plant to perform a

screening process to insure the work will be performed safely. 



Prior to appointing a contractor to a task, the following shall be evaluated: safety and performance history, certifications, job skills, and knowledge. Once appointed, the plant shall ensure the contractor is provided with the appropriate information concerning risks, hazards, emergency actions, and safe work actions to safely output the task given.



A site injury and illness log shall be maintained for contract employees who perform tasks on or near a process covered by the RMP regulations.  



It is the responsibility of the contract employer to ensure the contract employees are aware of the potential hazards involved and have the necessary skills and training to perform the designated task safely.  The contract employer shall provide training, document the training using the record given in Appendix C, and ensure safe working practices are used by the contract employees.  The pre-startup procedures along with the normal operating procedures shall be evaluated prior to start-up.



The WWTP Superintendent must be able to have free access to contractor work areas to ensure that safe work practices are being maintained.  Harrodsburg WWTP is also responsible for providing process safety information to contractors.  A copy of this document will suffice for the process safety requirement.



1.5.3    Mechanical Integrity



Review and maintenance of the "Operations and Maintenance Manual" (O&M) for the Harrodsburg WWTP is done in accordance with the management of change procedures detailed below.  Deviation from normal procedures can lead to releases of gaseous chlorine which, potentially within seconds, can lead to lethal concentrations of the gas.  See Section titled Operating Procedures for operational procedures adapted from the plant O&M manual.  The most serious and most frequent consequence of deviation from those procedures is a potentially life threatening release of chlorine gas.  Design crit

eria involved in the system comes from engineering plans in place with the Kentucky Division of Water and are based on suggested criteria from the Wallace and Tiernan Corporation, manufacturer of the ejectors, flow and pressure devices in the system.  Typically, the system can handle pressures up to 200 psi.  This pressure is not achieved in the cylinder until a temperature of 120 degrees Fahreheit is reached.  For this reason, the building should be well ventilated in hot weather.  There is no lower limit on either temperature or pressure.



All inspections and test performances shall be documented using the form in Appendix D.  In the event a deficiency is present, it shall be corrected before continued use or by means to operate safely.  



Living Waters is responsible for the integrity of the pressurized chlorine cylinders.  Living Waters  inspects the cylinders before delivering them to the site.



1.5.4    Hot Work Permit



No hot work is performed at the Harrodsburg WWTP currently.  The chlorination processes at the WWTP have no welded connections.  As such, hot work is not anticipated to take place on the system.



However, in the event that the facility performs work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark-producing operations on or near a covered process, the Harrodsburg WWTP will be required to issue a hot work permit.  The permit provides documentation that fire protection and prevention measures were in place prior to the work as required by the regulation.  A hot work permit is also used to identify the date of work and the object on which hot work is to be performed.  The permit shall be kept on file until the hot work is complete. 



1.5.5    Management of Change



A practice of management of change means that plant personnel may not alter any operations practices or policies or change piping or configuration of chlorine handling processes without going through certain steps.  The steps used to manage change at

the Harrodsburg WWTP are:



A?    Establishing the need for changes from the perspectives of safety, efficiency and technical/scientific soundness.



A?    Review and discussion of the changes with their coworkers and the Wastewater Plant Superintendent.



A?    Review of how the changes might affect the Process Hazard Analysis found elsewhere in this document.



A?    Discussion of the changes with all staff members who have duties associated with the chlorination system.



A?    Final approval of changes to the chlorine systems at the plant must be approved by the Water Plant Superintendent.



A?    Changes to the chlorine process must also be communicated to the local DES personnel so that they may determine if changes to the Emergency Response Plan, particularly the TAB-Q7, are needed.



A?    Before actually implementing any changes, all persons who have responsibility with the chlorination system should perform a pre-startup review (see below) of the written process changes or the physical changes proposed to be made.



Pre-startup Review 

After any changes to the chlorination system, a review of the changes will take place before startup of the revised system.  The review will be led by the Superintendent and will consist of the following four tasks.



1.    Confirm that the construction complies with the proposed plans and changes are consistent with state DOW and OSHA requirements if applicable.

2.    Confirm that changes to safety practices in this document and the O&M manual have been adjusted to reflect the system revisions.

3.    Revise the Process Hazard Analysis in this document if necessary.

4.    Confirm that training specified in Section 7 of this document has taken place.



When significant changes occur, a written statement demonstrating a pre-startup review should be drafted by the superintendent or his or her designee and kept on file with the revised piping diagrams at the WWTP as part of this document.



1.5.6    Compliance Audits



Compliance audits shall be p

erformed by an impartial, qualified employee, or team, knowledgeable of the process at a minimum of every three years and shall be documented using the form in Appendix F.  The design and effectiveness of the system shall be evaluated during a compliance audit, as well as the safety and health conditions on the floor.  Any findings that the procedures and/or practices regulated under this document are not being followed shall be documented and corrected promptly.  The two most recent compliance audit reports shall be kept on file.



1.6    Five Year Accident History



Within the past five years there have been no accidents pertaining to chlorine at this facility.



If a catastrophic or potentially catastrophic event occurs, the Harrodsburg WWTP shall investigate the event as early as possible, but no more than 48 hours following the incident, and shall establish an incident investigation team to prepare a report as shown in Appendix E.  The report shall be made to obtain facts that will be helpful in preventing similar occurances, but shall not be made to place blame.  All affected personnel shall review the report.  Report findings shall be addressed, documented, and retained for a minimum of five years.  



1.7    Emergency Response Program



The purpose of this section is to provide operators with the procedures that will be used in dealing with a leak or spill of chlorine. Spills and leaks of hazardous materials will be classified as one of the following:



Small Leak or Spill   Release of a chemical that may cause minor irritation to the eyes, throat or nose. A small leak on a cylinder or ton container is often stopped by shutting off the outlet/supply valve or by minor repairs.



Large Leak or Spill   Release of a chemical that will cause an immediate, painful burning sensation to the lungs, eyes, nose and/or throat. It will be characterized by a visible cloud of gas vapors or liquid escaping from a cylinder or drum. A large leak on a compressed gas cylinder

or container will also be accompanied by the noise of escaping gas. A large leak will be classified as potentially life threatening to an operator and the nearby population.  In the case of large leaks, the local DES should be contacted as outline in the DES TAB-Q-7 document attached as Appendix .G



The majority of small leaks will occur at either the outlet valve or the PVC feed line.



a) Operators will use the buddy system when investigating leaks.



b) Find a chlorine leak by using a commercial grade of ammonia in a squeeze bottle. Spray the ammonia vapor around the outlet valve and the feed line. When the ammonia vapor comes into contact with the leaking chlorine gas, a white cloud will form.



c) When the location of the leak has been found, shut off the outlet supply valve and make repairs (tighten the packing nut, replace the lead washer or PVC line).



d) If a one ton container of chlorine gas continues to leak after the outlet supply valve has been shut off, immediately notify the general manager, the assistant manager, and the wastewater treatment plant supervisor and/or the assistant chief operator and inform them of the situation. Telephone the chemical supplier to seek assistance in shutting off the container.



e) Note the occurrence of each leak in the daily log book.



Large Leak or Spill Repair Procedures



As stated previously, a large leak or spill will involve a quantity of hazardous material that escapes into the atmosphere and has a lethal potential for the plant operators/general public. With this in mind, the most important consideration in dealing with a large leak is the immediate notification of the proper authorities (see Appendix A).



In keeping with the county DES plans, water plant personnel are to leave the plant in the event of a chlorine leak or significant spill of any hazardous substance.  Significant means anything that cannot easily and certainly be handled by plant personnel on-site at the time of the release.  When

in doubt follow the DES procedure.  DES plans (Appendix A) require you to leave the plant and go to the staging area.  From there, dial 911 from your mobile phone.  If you do not have a mobile phone dial 911 from the plant before leaving if it is safe to do so.  Otherwise find a local phone at least as far away as the staging point and dial 911.  When notifying the police and fire departments (911), calmly explain the type of chemical involved in the emergency and the severity of the hazardous chemical release. Also provide the wind direction or the direction any hazardous gas vapor may be traveling so that civilian evacuation downwind can be properly planned and executed.



It is not anticipated at this time that WWTP personnel will assist in response efforts for a large spill.  An outside firm is expected to be contracted for such incidents.



All accidents/incidents involving hazardous chemicals should be documented carefully using the Incident Report Form found as Appendix E.  This should be completed by plant personnel regardless of what outside agency responds to incidents.  Copies of these forms should be kept in the main WWTP office.  



1.8    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



No changes are needed at this time.  The plant shall maintain the practices as stated within this document for operations to remain safe for the community/public and process employees.  As time goes on, changes within the facility or within regulations will result in re-evaluation and updates of this plan.

PROTECTIVE ACTIONS:    Isolate the leak or spill area for 500 feet (small spill) to 1500 feet (large

spill) in all directions. After that is established, initiate protective actions the extent possible, beginning

with those closest to the spill site and working away from the site in a downwind direction. The Area of 

Concern for Sulfur Dioxide is 9 miles. The Area of Concern for Chlorine is 10 miles. The WWTP is

located in a semi-rural area, with the Area of Concern in a Southeast direction encompassing the entire

City of Harrodsburg, the City of Burgin and a portion of the Northwest outskirts of the City of Danville.

Also included in the Area of Concern, to the South and West is the City of Perryville and a small portion 

of Washington County.



In the event an evacuation is selected over an in-place shel

tering order, direct all persons to move in 

upwind or crosswind directions, away from the leak/spill area. Evacuation routes will, of course, be 

determined primarily by wind direction at the time of the incident. General evacuation routes will be US 

127 (North and South), US 68 (East and West) and KY 152 (East and West). Persons living on lesser 

roads than those mentioned should work their way to the general evacuation routes, taking care to move in 

upwind or crosswind directions. Due to the close proximity of the facilities mentioned to the plant, the 

time factor involved may make evacuation an extremely unsafe option. Additionally, should the chemical 

leak or spill be small in volume or short-lived, in-place sheltering might be a preferable option. In-place 

sheltering should be carried out by advising persons in the vulnerable zone to stay indoors, close all doors 

and windows, shut down all air conditioning and ventilation units and move to the center of the building 

until notified that the emergency is over. The initial notification and further advisement's will be made by 

telephone (primarily to the large factories and the schools), public address announcements from 

emergency vehicles as possible, as well as local radio and television broadcasts. Initial or temporary

evacuation centers for an incident would be set up at one or more of several locations selected as 

necessary. The County Judge Executive or DES officials (i.e. the Incident Commander) will determine 

when re-entry to the affected area is safe.

NOTE: The average rate for air change per hour (acph) in "average" American homes and office-type 

buildings, under average conditions, is 0.8 to 1.0 acph with doors and windows closed and ventilation

systems closed down. "Leaky" buildings or average buildings exposed to severe weather conditions, with

acph rates of 1.5 to 2.5, may experience 45 to 65% of outdoor concentrations within 30 minutes. If a

structure is exposed to ha

zardous conditions for an extended period of time, the chemical concentration

inside the structure may approach the outside concentration. Therefore, in-place sheltering is generally

applicable for releases of short duration (30 minutes or less) and may have limited application for releases

that exceed a period of time in excess of one hour.



The local hospitals (Haggin Memorial Hospital in Harrodsburg and Ephraim McDowell Regional Medical 

Center in Danville) are capable of handling the first aid and medical care required for exposure to 

Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide, although only Ephraim McDowell Memorial has HazMat level 

decontamination capabilities. Protective Actions for the adjacent affected counties would be most

expeditiously handled through wide area media coverage (Lexington television and radio stations) and

through existing emergency notification procedures in place for those counties.

*** Evacuation instructions for the adjacent affected counties follow:

Evacuate the area within the Area of Concern (or radius) in an upwind or crosswind direction.



EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT ON HAND/TRAINING/EXERCISING:    (EQUIPMENT) A chlorine

leak detector and a Sulfur Dioxide leak detector are installed at the WWTP. There is one SCBA on hand 

at the WWTP. One Chlorine B-kit (emergency capping kit for ton containers) is located at the WWTP 

plant.

(TRAINING) Familiarization seminars, put on by the Chlorine supplier, have been held in Harrodsburg

and attended by both Water Department personnel and Harrodsburg Fire Department personnel.

The training is to AWARENESS LEVEL ONLY.

(EXERCISING) Water Department personnel work with the Harrodsburg Fire Department, Mercer 

County Fire Departments, Harrodsburg Police Department & the LEPC to schedule response exercises.

The most recent training exercise was held on 8/21/98 at the Harrodsburg Wastewater Plant.

COMMUNITY RESOURCES: The local fire departments maintain their own emergency equipment.

Refer to the Mer

cer Co. EOP (ERIL) for additional resources. The fire department is trained to

AWARENESS LEVEL ONLY. 



SPILL CONTAINMENT/CLEAN-UP/DISPOSAL:    (SPILL CONTAINMENT) Per the DOT

Emergency Response Guidebook and the MSDS for Chlorine, water spray can be used to reduce chlorine

vapor but DO NOT apply water to the leak or spill area. If the leak cannot be stopped without risk,

isolate the area until the gas has dispersed. 

NOTE that a leak from a container can be slowed by rotating the container so that gas rather than liquid

Escapes from it, i.e., rotate the container so the leak is at or near the uppermost side of the container.

Spill containment for Sulfur Dioxide is the same as for Chlorine outlined above.

(CLEAN-UP/DISPOSAL) Chlorine can be absorbed in alkaline solutions. Common solutions are

Caustic Soda and Soda Ash. The WWTP does not maintain any alkaline solutions of any appreciable

quantity at the facility. The WTP Plant, located 7 miles EAST of the City Limits, does maintain an

inventory of Caustic Soda for water treatment use, however, it would take 2,500 lbs. of 100% Caustic

Soda, or 6,000 pounds of Soda Ash, to neutralize 1 ton of chlorine. These quantities of those two 

chemicals are not kept on hand by the City, but in the event they are used to contain or clean up a spill, 

they would be provided by a private contractor (listed below). Cleanup and disposal of the chemical would 

also be handled by the HazMat contractors (listed below).
